description.narrative: Wildlife crime is combated on the ground through strengthening enforcement operations in targeted protected area complexes & Community Conservancies are created in terms of the Conservation Act, effectively expanding Gorongosa National Park

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
PROJECT OBJECTIVE Indicator 1. IRR Output 2.5 indicator 2.5.1: Extent to which national legal, policy, and institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems.
Indicator 2. Number of direct project beneficiaries: - (UNDAF indicator 9.4.2): Nº. of communities benefiting from NRM related revenues - Number of local people in project areas benefiting from engagement in conservation activities and/or improved livelihoods attributable to the project (male/female)
Indicator 3. Number of individuals of IWT flagship species (e.g. lion, cheetah, leopard, rhino, elephant) at the project sites (site level)
OUTCOME 1 Indicator 1. Presence of operational coordination mechanism to implement W&FC Strategy
Indicator 2. Capacity of ANAC on IWT control as indicated by customized UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard
OUTCOME 2 Indicator 1. Results of law enforcement on poaching and IWT in the project areas (site level): a. # of law enforcement staff/km²[1] b. # of patrol person-days/month c. # of arrests/patrol month f. # of wildlife/wildlife product seizures at program sites[4] /year g. # of investigations that lead to arrests of wildlife/wildlife / products smugglers/ a year h. # of prosecutions of wildlife/wildlife product smugglers / year
OUTCOME 4 Indicator 1. Number of project lessons on IWT control and CBNRM used in development and implementation of other conservation projects, with at least one lesson on gender mainstreaming
Indicator 2. (a)Number of national and international organizations that participate in the project M&E and provide feedback to the Management Team; (b) % of women among all participants of the project activities, including M&E

comment.narrative:
PROJECT OBJECTIVE Indicator 1.: - No National W&FC and IWT Strategy adopted - No WCU exists
Indicator 2.: - 42 (2014) - 44,263 (male) - 47,442 (female)
Indicator 3.: - Elephants: 4900 - Big cats: 4500
OUTCOME 1 Indicator 1.: - No coordination mechanism in place
Indicator 2.: - Score of 43
OUTCOME 2 Indicator 1.: a.0.0053 b. 1800 c .0.4 f. 30 g. 2 h. 1
OUTCOME 4 Indicator 1.: - 0
Indicator 2.: a) At least 5 in PSC b) 5%

-Number of direct project beneficiaries: - (UNDAF indicator 9.4.2): Nº. of communities benefiting from NRM related revenues 52 -Number of local people in project areas benefiting from engagement in conservation activities and/or improved livelihoods attributable to the project (male/female) 50,263 (female) 57,442 (male) Number of individuals of IWT flagship species (e.g. lion, cheetah, leopard, rhino, elephant) at the project sites (site level) Results of law enforcement on poaching and IWT in the project areas (site level): a. # of law enforcement staff/km²[1] 0.006 b. # of patrol personday/month-2000 c. # of arrests/patrol month :2 f. # of wildlife/wildlife product seizures at program sites[4] /year: 60 g. # of investigations that lead to arrests of wildlife/wildlife / products smugglers/ a year h. # of prosecutions of wildlife/wildlife product smugglers / year: 10 - Level of management effectiveness at site level as measured by METT score: 72 Total number/area of new conservancies officially established in the project areas (ha) : GRP: 1/35,000 - Annual number of HWC in conservancy area :80 - # of integrated landscape management plans implemented:2 - Area (ha) under SLM/SFM :450

-Design of the W&FC and IWT strategy started in 2020 not concluded as of limitations caused by COVID19 -On ground anti-crime operations involving ANAC, PPRNMA (Environmental Police), Environmental Quality Agency(AQUA), and Investigation Police(SERNIC- -Four security plans were carried out in 3 national parks and 1 national reserve - This year 2020 will complete one more year in which no elephants have been recorded as lost to ivory poaching in Niassa Special Reserve. - Niassa Special Reserve has developed a local Law Enforcement (LE) strategic plan under the aegis of the CITES MIKES program. The has been to maintain the improvement in patrol intensity in the Reserve with NSR foot patrols now achieving on average 1,268.8 kms (NSR only) and 3,719.4 km (combined with operators) on foot per month. - Create and deploy fire response team -The total number of local people benefiting for the project is currently 5286 --Several operations were held on the ground by ANAC, PPRNMA (Environmental Police), AQUA(Environmental Quality Agency) for detention and seizure of illegal wildlife products in local markets among other suspicious sites; -ANAC has stablished a permanent inter-institutional collaboration with relevant institutions for IWT such as Investigation Police (SERNIC), Secret Services, Environmental Police, Justice Sector ( a deputy prosecutor specifically assigned to this area) and Immigration Services -A total of 16 training sessions on conservation legislation and importance of conserving forests were implemented with members from the 16 NRMCs, community leaders, district government representatives and community members

-Number of direct project beneficiaries: - (UNDAF indicator 9.4.2): Nº. of communities benefiting from NRM related revenues 52 -Number of local people in project areas benefiting from engagement in conservation activities and/or improved livelihoods attributable to the project (male/female) 50,263 (female) 57,442 (male) Number of individuals of IWT flagship species (e.g. lion, cheetah, leopard, rhino, elephant) at the project sites (site level) Results of law enforcement on poaching and IWT in the project areas (site level): a. # of law enforcement staff/km²[1] 0.006 b. # of patrol personday/month-2000 c. # of arrests/patrol month :2 f. # of wildlife/wildlife product seizures at program sites[4] /year: 60 g. # of investigations that lead to arrests of wildlife/wildlife / products smugglers/ a year h. # of prosecutions of wildlife/wildlife product smugglers / year: 10 - Level of management effectiveness at site level as measured by METT score: 72 Total number/area of new conservancies officially established in the project areas (ha) : GRP: 1/35,000 - Annual number of HWC in conservancy area :80 - # of integrated landscape management plans implemented:2 - Area (ha) under SLM/SFM :450

A number of arrests and conventions have already been made, including seizure of 12 pangolins, 1 leopard skin and 11 elephant tusks. A total of 12 ivory traffickers arrested and prosecuted, 16 pangolin traffickers arrested and prosecuted, a notorious elephant poacher arrested and prosecuted Initial consultations have taken place in all six districts straddling Gorongosa National Park (GNP, with in-depth consultations in 9 communities (regulados, including 574 males and 339 females) representing approx. 6,400 community members. Areas identified in Condue/Muanza area and initial consultations under way; GNP purchased forestry concession of CMM (28,560 ha) and adds these to the community managed SFM area Elephants: > 600 increased to 658 in 2018 Big cats: > 100 lions increased to 146 in 2018 Wild dogs: > 14 (introduced in 2018) Developed plan for Coutada 12, which is currently under management of GNP. A new 30-year strategy and a first 5-year Business Plan have been drafted and will be implemented from 2020 onwards. The Gorongosa Restoration Project has established a strong working relationship with the Namibia Association of CBNRM Support Organizations (NACSO), a well-established NGO convening a huge amount of expertise in CBNRM and Conservancy work in Namibia. An active knowledge exchange is taking place, strongly enriching the community engagement work at Gorongosa. Linkages to sharing lessons learnt at the national level have also been established, noticing that the national CBNRM and Community Conservancy related policy framework needs revision to support local needs.

-National W&FC and IWT Strategy adopted by GoM and started with the implementation -WCU is established with at least 3 technical staff - -Nº. of communities benefiting from NRM related revenues 52 -Presence of operational coordination mechanism to implement W&FC Strategy -Annual number of HWC in conservancy area
